updateData.functionBody: return apogeeutil.textRequest(worldCasesUrl);
return apogeeutil.textRequest(usCasesUrl);
return simpleCsvParser(usCasesData);
return simpleCsvParser(usDeathsData);
return apogeeutil.textRequest(usDeathsUrl);
return apogeeutil.textRequest(worldDeathsUrl);
return apogeeutil.textRequest(worldRecoveredUrl);
return simpleCsvParser(worldDownloadedData);
return simpleCsvParser(worldDeathsData);
return simpleCsvParser(worldRecoveredData);
return row.slice(columnDefs.FIRST_DATA_ROW).map(stringValue => parseInt(stringValue));
return table[0].slice(columnDefs.FIRST_DATA_ROW).map( value => value.trim());
return apogeeutil.jsonRequest(usStatePopulationUrl + "&key=" + apiKey);

return [
    {
        type: "checkboxGroup",
        label: "Plot Data: ",
        entries: [["Filtered Data","filteredData"],["Raw Data","rawData"]],
        horizontal: true,
        groupName: "plotDataType",
        key: "plotDataType"
    } /*,
    {
        type: "radioButtonGroup",
        label: "Y Scale: ",
        entries: [["Linear","linear"],["Logarithmic","logarithmic"]],
        horizontal: true,
        groupName: "scaleType",
        key: "scaleType"
    }   */ 
]

//If data valid, return true. If data is invalid, return an error message.
return true;

//If data valid, return true. If data is invalid, return an error message.
return true;
return usProcessedData.dateLabels;
return graphingUtilities.createGraphData(usDataEntry,selectedStateEntries,rawDateLabels,options);
return usProcessedData.cleanedData;

if((!stateSelector.data)||(!stateSelector.data.states)) return apogeeutil.INVALID_VALUE;

return stateSelector.data.states;

if(labelList) return labelList;
else throw new Error("Invalid label list!");
return regionList.map( regionName => parentDataEntry.regions[regionName] )

if(processedCasesData.length < 1) return [];

return processedCasesData[0].labelArray;

if(processedDeathsData.length < 1) return [];

return processedDeathsData[0].labelArray;

let title = "COVID Cases per " + CASES_PER + " Residents";
return createChartOptions(title,yAxisType);

let title = "COVID New Cases per " + CASES_PER + " Residents";
return createChartOptions(title,yAxisType);

let title = "COVID Deaths per " + CASES_PER + " Residents";
return createChartOptions(title,yAxisType);

let title = "COVID New Deaths per " + CASES_PER + " Residents";
return createChartOptions(title,yAxisType);

return [
    {
        type: "checkboxGroup",
        label: "Plot Data: ",
        entries: [["Filtered Data","filteredData"],["Raw Data","rawData"]],
        horizontal: true,
        groupName: "plotDataType",
        key: "plotDataType"
    } /*,
    {
        type: "radioButtonGroup",
        label: "Y Scale: ",
        entries: [["Linear","linear"],["Logarithmic","logarithmic"]],
        horizontal: true,
        groupName: "scaleType",
        key: "scaleType"
    }   */ 
]

//If data valid, return true. If data is invalid, return an error message.
return true;

//If data valid, return true. If data is invalid, return an error message.
return true;
return graphingUtilities.createGraphData(stateDataEntry,selectedCountyEntries,rawDateLabels,options);
return usProcessedData.dateLabels;
return usProcessedData.cleanedData;
return stateSelector.data.state;
return usDataEntry.regions[selectedState];
return piecewiseLinearModel.createTridiag(workingInputData.length);
return piecewiseLinearModel.createBVector(workingInputData);
return tridiagPage.tridiagSolver(AMatrix,bVector);
return tridiagSolver(AMatrix,bVector);
return tridiagMultiply(AMatrix,xVector);
return bezierInterpolatedData.map( entry => entry.y);
return bezierInterpolatedData.map( entry => entry.dydx);
return inData.map( value => value*multiplier);
return dataDownload.usCasesGrid.filter( (row,index) => (index == 0)||(row[inputCasesColumns["STATE"]] == "Alabama")||(row[inputCasesColumns["STATE"]] == "Missippi") );
return dataDownload.usDeathsGrid.filter( (row,index) => (index == 0)||(row[inputDeathsColumns["STATE"]] == "Alabama")||(row[inputDeathsColumns["STATE"]] == "Missippi") );
return dataDownload.US_CASES_COLUMNS;
return dataDownload.US_DEATHS_COLUMNS;
return row.slice(columnDefs.FIRST_DATA_ROW).map(stringValue => parseInt(stringValue));

content.text: Data Download
This data is downloaded from a Github site managed by Johns Hopkins:
https://github.com/CSSEGISandData/COVID-19
World Data
The url below is raw world cases data in csv format.
The url below is raw world deaths data in csv format.
The url below is raw world recovered data in csv format.
Here is the raw downloaded cases data:
Here is the raw downloaded deathsdata:
Here is the raw downloaded recovered data:
Here is the world cases data processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Here is the world deaths data processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Here is the world recovered data processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Below is the column numbering for the data, with the first column being column 0. This applies to all three world tables.
These are the data labels for the world data.
US Data
The url below is raw cases data in csv format for the US.
The url below is raw cases data in csv format for the US.
Here is the raw cases data.
Here is the raw deaths data.
Here is the US cases processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Here is the US deaths processed in to a row and column array. The field header is kept on.
Below are some column numbers from the above grid, with the first column being column 0. This only applies to the cases data. The deaths data has an additional column, population.
Below are some column numbers from the deaths grid data, with the first column being 0. Note that this table contains one additional column not in the cases data.
Data Access Utilities
This function gets the time series data for a given row.
This function gets the data labels for a given table. The table should be the grid data table.
Simple CSV Parser

This is a simple CSV parser. It will work if there are ZERO or ONE of the internal fields that are quote delimited. It will throw an error if this condition is not met. This works with our current input data.
Workspace Notes
This page contains various notes regarding the workspace, such as items I want to go back and improve.
To Do
I should rearrange the pages a little. Maybe have top level entries data, plots, tools
To Improve
The parsing of the text data is really a cludge. I will parse the data if there are 0 or 1 fields that are delimited with quotes (because of an included comma). I should generalize this.
Right now I have a lot of code in a number of cells.
Other Issues
The grids will often get corrupted  (I think if you scroll from the top and leave the page). This is a bug in my grid view.
Population Data
Global Settings
We will plot the number of cases per the following population in our graphs where we graph per population count.
US Population Data
This is a URL to download state population from the US Census. Unfortunately I haven't figured out how to get data for the US territories included in the COVID data.
Here is the API key.
Here is the data.
Here is the data reformatted into a lookup table.
World Population Table
This is a 2020 population of countries taken from the web  page
https://worldpopulationreview.com/
US Processed Data
This is data processed from the US datasets.
Formatted Data
Here we combine the cases and deaths data.
Here we clean up the data:
delete entries with incomplete data (There are some territories at the end)
add the counts from counties and put these in the state entries.
Data Lists
This is a list of states that have cases and death data available at the state level.
This is a list of states that have cases and deaths available at the county level.
This is the label list for the data.
Tests
Here we do a few additional checks. The array result should be a list of errors.
US State COVID Plots
We will plot the number of cases per the following population for the given states
This form gets some options for the graphs.
This form selects the states to plot.
Charts
The following charts give the number cases, new cases, deaths and new deaths scaled by population size.
Chart Data
Here is our compiled chart data.
Data Inputs
This are the date labels for the original data.
This is the input data entry - the US country entry.
These are the selected states.
Options
These are the options used to create the graph data.
This is the filtering constant that is used for this data.
These are the data series to plot
This is the axis type:
End
End2
Create Graph Data
This function..
Input Data
Output
Default Options
These are the default options that will be used if the options are not specified.
Data Processing
This is the reference population used for scaling the output.
This is the filtering constant that is used for this data.
These are the date labels
These are the data entries for the selected states.
These are the data series to plot
This is the axis type:
Here is the processed state data, showing the number of new cases per given population number as given by the field
casesPer
These are the labels for the cases data.
This is the processed deaths data.
These are the data labels for the processed deaths data.
Chart Data
These are some input data sets created for the charts.
Chart Source Functions
This creates a data set for a chart.
This creates chart options for a chart.
These labels are used for line style selection for datasets
US County Plots
We will plot the number of cases per the following population for the given counties in the selected states.
This form gets some options for the graphs.
This form selects the states to plot.
Charts
The following charts give the number cases, new cases, deaths and new deaths scaled by population size.
Chart Data
Here is our compiled chart data.
Data Inputs
This are the date labels for the original data.
This is the input data entry - the US country entry.
This is the selected state:
This is the selected state entry
These are the selected states.
Options
These are the options used to create the graph data.
This is the filtering constant that is used for this data.
These are the data series to plot
This is the axis type:
E
Data Processing Utilities
Smoothing
This function smooths the data. For documentation open the associated child page.
NOTE: This function will alter the data series length!
Time Series Manipulation
This function takes a difference of entries. To end up with the same length of array, this creates a virtual entry of index -1 with value 0.
This function divides each entry by the input number
COVID Smoothing Estimator
This is a function that smooths the COVID data. Note that the data array may have some samples trimmed from the start, to fit a length requirement based on the filter size parameter N.
Inputs
This is the input array of data samples.
This is the filtering parameters in units of days (or whatever the X axis units are). This is the period over which data is averaged.
This is an optional array of labels. The input data may have truncated samples from the start of the array. If this value is input, the return value will include a similarly truncated label array.
Outputs
This is the output. It includes the following fields:
modifiedDataArray = This is the input data array as processed. It may have samples truncated from the start of the input data array.
modifiedLabelArray - If included, this will be returned. It and the data array may have samples removed from the start.
filteredDataArray - This is the filter data array.
filteredDifferenceArray - This is an estimate of the rate of change of the data array, in terms of the change between successive days.
intermediateDataArray - This is a piecewise linear curve that estimates the data array. This is an intermediate stage of the smoothing calculation.
Business Logic
Modified Input Arrays
Our current calculation requires the proper number of points, so we will modify the input arrays here by truncating extra points from the
front
of the array (since that data is less interesting).
Piece-wise Line Fitting Calculation
We will break out interval into fixed size segments, given by Model.N. We will use least squares to find a series of line segment, length N, that best fit the input data.
This is the tridiagonal matrix to find the solution
This is the b vector to find the solution.
This is the solution for the points at the end of the line segments.
Here we expand the data to give a value for each point in the original data set.
Bezier Interpolation
The above solution is a series of straight line segments. Here we will define bezier segments to get a smoother interpolation.

The bezier points will be placed at the midpoint X of each of our line segments. The slope to the control points will be the slope of the line. We choose a length to the control points to be 1/3 the distance of between the main points. This is choosen mainly because it makes associating X and the bezier t parameter easy. (That is a weak reason. This strength of these control points could be an input. If this is done, the conversino from t to x must be improved.)

As for the Y value of our bezier points, they will be moved slightly from the midpoint Y value of our line segments. Curvature of the data will force the line midpoints to be above (or below) the actual data value at the midpoint X. We will attempt to correct for this offset.
This first cell collects some information for each line segment in our above solution.
This next cell calculate the Y value offset for our bezier points based off of the curvature. The curvature is measured from the change in the line segment slopes.

NOTE: The correction I derived should translate both the X and Y values for the bezier point. However, for now at least, I am requiring the X values be the specified numbers, purely because I this gives an easy correspondence between X and the bezier T parameter. If I do a proper calculation between x and t, then I can move the X values, meaning I can change the control point lengths and add other corrections to the X point values.
Below we create the collection of Bezier segments.

Since the bezier segments are offset from the line segments, we need a little more data at the start and end. We will create additional data at the start and end by extending the first and last line segments with a constant slope.
This boundary condition does have a noticable impact on the data. We might want to look at other treatments.
Here we get the interpolated data for both the data and its derivative, since we are interested in the change in our data also.
Here we extract the interpolated date.
Here we extract the interpolated slope.
Piecewise Linear Model

This page contains code necessary to create a piecewise linear model for a data sample. The basic idea is to place a reference point every N points of our input data, and fit the best set of these points.
To use this page, the value N, the linear segment length in samples, must be defined within the scope of this pace.
Parameters

Doing a least squares fit of the data will create a tridiagonal system. The coefficients of the fitted parameters (the A matrix) do not depend on the data. The data is only present in the b Vector (in the equations b = Ax),
The following two parameters compose the tridiagonal matrix.
Model Creation Functions
For now I will assume the data has a number of points so we don't have any odd sized segments.
We will model the tridiagonal A matrix by giving only the tridiagonal elements (so the dimensions of the matrix are m x 3).
Tridiagonal Matrix Solver
Tridiagonal Solver Functions
This function returns the solution vector for the passed tridiagonal system. The matrix A should consist of the tridiagonal elements. It is a matrix with only 3 columns.
This function multiplies a tridiagonal matrix by a vector.
Test
This is the input matrix. It should have dimensions of N x 3 and model a tridiagonal matrix.
This is the b vector for the equation bVector = AMatrix * xVector;
This is the result vector from the input calculation
Here we mutliply our solution to see it matches the original b vector.
World Processed Data
This is data processed from the world datasets.
REVIEW THIS! I THINK I WANT TO PROCESS IT DIFFERENT
for one thing I did not add the population data
Formatted Data
Here we combine the cases and deaths data.
Here we clean up the data:
if there are state (/province) entries, use these to fill in missing data in the country entry
delete an state/province entries
Data Lists
This is a list of states that have cases and death data available at the state level.
This is the label list for the data.
Tests
Here we do a few additional checks. The array result should be a list of errors.
Merge Grid Data
This page function takes the input cases and deaths grid and merges them into a single JSON data structure.
Inputs
This is the cases grid
This is the column definitions for the cases grid.
This is the deaths grid.
This is the column definitions for the deaths grid.
This is the column name for the parent admin region for these grids.
This is the column name for the child admin region for these grids.
Output
This is the merged data structure created from the input data.
Processing
This is the first step of combining the data. We will just combine data from the grid into the final format. We will however do some additional processing below before returning it.
We want to do a few checks and potential fixes on the data
If the parent entry is missing data and there are child entries (for example state and country, for example) we will combine the child entries to populate he parent entry.
If any data is not present, we will discard the entry.
The above processing aplies to the following fields:
cases time series data
deaths time series data
lat and lon
population
I NEED TO FIX BELOW. I PROBABLY SHOULD MAKE THIS INTO MULTIPLE CELLS
filter out incomplete children
sum children where needed
filter out incomplete parents - WAIT, THERE SHOULD BE NO INCOMPLETE PARENTS IF THE CHILDREN ARE COMPLETE.
OR MAYBE I SHOULD DO THIS AL TOGETHER DIFFERENTLY?
Utility Functions
This function gets the time series data for a given row.
This function reads lat lon data from a row. It returns null if there is not valid data.
This function reads population data frof a row, if it is present. It returns null if there is not valid data.
